rComments: As someone who enjoys the subject, I was completely disappointed. I am happy that I already had knowledge of the subject, otherwise I would have completely been screwed. I have heard from other students his class screws you for 6C, and with how little I learned, I definitely am afraid to take it in the fall.

Worst prof at UCSC. Totally unaccommodating if you are a DRC student. Nice dude, but you won't learn what you need to from him if you plan to take more physics classes. Had to teach myself everything, might as well have taken $1000 out of the bank and set it on fire. Total waste of time.

Zack is by far the worst Professor that I have ever had at. His lectures are useless, so you'll either have to learn from MSI or some other platform. I received A's on both midterms and on the homework, but ended up with a B in the class. His final was not like any of the course material, resulting in a drop of an entire letter grade for students.

His tests are really easy, but hes going to severely under prepare you for phys6C. The things you are expected to know going into phys6C he said were too hard for phys6A. He's either then not confident in his teaching ability, or he's not confident in his students to learn. In all, he needed to better prepare us for the rest of the physics series.

Zack's lectures may come off as very lengthy and boring, but I promise you that if you muster the courage to pay attention during class, you will understand most of what he is doing, and be able to catch his sense of humor as well :) Physics in general is a really tough class, but take advantage of office hours; he's definitely a worthwhile teacher

Zack is a good professor. His lectures can get a little boring, but he spends more time on problem-solving than on theory. Tests are very straightforward, and he doesn't throw any curveballs or trick problems at you. He's organized and usually posts lectures on his blog, explaining how to do homework problems. He posts practice tests too.

Single midterm and a final. Homework is now online, passing the cost of grading from the school to the students (thanks, regents!). The class has like a bajillion people in it, so it's hard to pay attentions. He does examples all day long. If you did AP Physics and did well, you don't really need to go to/stay awake in lecture.

Zack was really great for this 20-something student class. No textbook, so lecture is very important to go to, and he can seem a little scattered at times, with no hard schedule for the class, but Zack is very good at figuring out and matching the flow of the students, noticing where people are struggling and excelling on a day to day basis.

The average physics class. He made the first and only midterm super easy and thee average was around 85. To compensate for this he seemingly made the final much harder because I somehow dropped from a low A to a C as my final grade. He needs to allocate credit more efficiently but other than that he's alright, don't underestimate his tests though.

Honestly I have never been so frustrated with a professor. He seems unable or unwilling to help on problems with the online homework and often does not fully lecture on the topic before the assignment is due. I really like physics and it's sad to think others had him for an introduction. Sure he gives practice problems, but what prof. doesn't?
Very fair professor. You need to attend lecture to pass his class.

He is very laid back. He didn't have a syllabus, he didn't seem to have a plan and we only used the textbook for integral tables. I really liked the class, as he seemed to be learning as much as we were and got very excited over things. He really engages with students and gives good explanations. The midterm and final were harder than I expected.

This class felt much more like a seminar than anything else.  Schlesinger certainly did the lecturing, but all the same there was a lot of back and forth between him and us.  Seems much more interested in physics than satisfying any prejudice that only a few people are capable of doing what he does.  Compared it to music during office hours.

There was no plan for the class, no textbook. Most of the material in the first half of the class involved tediously calculating expectation values and graphing wavefunctions. The 2nd half was hand-waving explanations of topics that were too advanced to cover in a mathematically precise way. I didn't enjoy either of these. Very smart guy though.

If you attend class and go to his office hours it is hard to not get an A because he tells you what problems to expect on the midterm and the problems are fair. Overall a nice and funny guy. I would recommend taking him.

Great Professor! Midterms are fair as long as you attend class and do the practice midterm he posts. He isn't like most other professors that just throws equations at you and then gives you extremely hard problems on the midterm. Attending office hours is very helpful since he pretty much tells you what problems are going to be on the midterm.

Zack is an awesome professor. You have to go to lecture and you have to pay attention if you want to pass the class. He really simplified things down and his test were more than fair.He takes students feedback about homework, test, class time pretty much everything. Physics is hard no matter what,he made it simple!plus he's hilarious!

I am confused by all the negative comments. His exams are completely fair and everything on them he covered in class, on the blog or in the reviews. I didn't like him at first but I warmed up; he's actually quite hilarious and helpful. I liked him way better than Smith, though he can be a little disorganized at times.
Schlesinger is not good at teaching. In lecture he does a bunch of problems without explaining what he does.

wow i hated this class. his lectures are really boring and not clear at all. When I tried to study for the test, I just gave up because I had no idea what he wanted us to learn. On the final I made a bunch of stuff up and I passed....so thats good I guess?
Class is a joke.  Can't believe this guy won an award for his teaching  methods ...  Retire, please.

Zack is quite a unique professor, and I encourage you to speak to a former pupil before taking one of his classes --- some like, some hate. He doesn't keep a lesson plan; rather, asks students what he should teach. Frequently he's unable to do thehomework
good teacher, but a little disorganised in thoughts. also, it might be the class, but some kids seem like they know the material way better than he does

the class was pretty difficult for me(hello quantum mechanics), however, zack's teaching style made teh the classroom atmosphere very conducive to learning and "teamwork".  in order to do well in the class you probably need to take a good chunk of time to go to office hours and study groups

Pretty much anyone who complains about Zack doesn't really understand what he's trying to do, which is make you think for yourself, not spoon feed you. Sure sometimes he doesn't wanna confront something in class, but he's very approachable and helpful after class or in office hours.  Generally a good teacher!
We deal with the most complicated stuff ever and we're doing 6th grade algebra. He can be funny at times, but it's a waste of time most of the time.

his teaching style makes it hard to understand because he's confusing. make sure you do the homework and most of all know how to do the review tests. he gives some test questions that are some what on the same lines as those in the review.
No Comments

You'll need to adapt to his teaching style. At first I didn't like it at all, but give it time. He has no formal lectures; rather he runs each class like a big problem solving session. He also understands that we might not be into physics, so his tests are very straightforward with no tricks (the online hmwk is way tougher). got an A, no sweat.

I absolutely loved Zack. A lot of people complained, but he's absolutely fair in grading and I appreciate that he teaches you how to tackle the problem head on as opposed to throwing a bunch of theory at you and expecting you to teach yourself how to apply it. Office hours were very helpful. If you want to do well, make sure you go to MSI.

Zach was constantly unprepared and disorganized.  He would spend 20minutes doing one problem only to find out that he did it wrong.  He's a nice guy but who cares he's not your friend, he's your professor and a little confidence in him would be good.
The guy tries his best, has a PhD from Cornell.  What more can you ask for.  He does not have the god-given talent to be one of the best lecturers in UCSC, but give the man credit for trying.

I ask myself, why this guy is a tenured professor. I mean, he cannot even integrate x^2 in class. He comes unprepared, mumbles meaningless stuff and on top thinks he is cool. I think he is almost as smart as an ashtray, but not quite. I hope he retires soon because then UCSC will clearly increase in school ratings.
No Comments

Rather than just giving you answers to your questions, he will make you think. He doesn't want you to memorize stuff; he wants you to understand it. The relativity part of the class is pretty easy, but the QM-part is harder.

If think Zack is out of it, you are gullible. Zack is good at playing dumb, it seems it is meant to make you think for yourself. It is true, he can be hard to understand at times,  but you only lose if you are lazy. Has a deep understanding of QM, you can gain if you care to. Take responsibility!
never take a class with him. it's a waste of time. as someone else wrote: physics degree from kmart?
He seems to have responded to criticism and gotten his act together. He's helpful and knows his stuff, but his lecture style can be a little confusing.

Zack teaches upper div. classic mech. wonderfully. He asks students to use intuition and to think about physical problems before tackling them with equations. I've taken Quantum from him also--not so good. Means well and ALWAYS approachable. Go 2 O.Hours
No Comments
Wow, did he even pass college physics??
I think there's an h-bar here... or was it here?
